problem: Find the integer $n,$ $0 \le n \le 180,$ such that $\cos n^\circ = \cos 568^\circ.$
solution:
Since the cosine function has period $360^\circ,$
\[\cos 568^\circ = \cos (568^\circ - 2 \cdot 360^\circ) = \cos (-152^\circ).\]And since the cosine function is even, $\cos (-152^\circ) = \cos 152^\circ,$ so $n = \boxed{152}.$
model_solution:
Step 1: Recall that the cosine function is periodic with period $360^\circ.$
Step 2: Since the cosine function is periodic with period $360^\circ,$ we can reduce $568^\circ$ modulo $360^\circ$ to obtain an equivalent angle in the interval $[0^\circ,360^\circ).$
Step 3: Reduce $568^\circ$ modulo $360^\circ$ to obtain an equivalent angle in the interval $[0^\circ,360^\circ).$
Step 4: The remainder when $568^\circ$ is divided by $360^\circ$ is $208^\circ,$ so $\cos 568^\circ = \cos 208^\circ.$
Step 5: Since the cosine function is an even function, $\cos(-\theta) = \cos \theta$ for any angle $\theta,$ then $\cos 208^\circ = \cos (180^\circ+28^\circ) = \cos 28^\circ.$
Step 6: $n=28$
Step 7: Since $0 \le n \le 180,$ then $n = 28.$
Since the cosine function is an even function, $\cos(-\theta) = \cos \theta$ for any angle $\theta,$ then $\cos 208^\circ = \cos (180^\circ+28^\circ) = \cos 28^\circ.$
$n = 28.$
